prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Specific factors articulated by the Panel—Number of actions

para.paratext: The Panel clearly considers the number of actions in deciding whether transfer is appropriate. It typically recites the number of actions pending and the number of districts in which they pend early in virtually every decision and, where applicable, the number of known additional actions filed after the transfer motion was filed. The number of actions does not play a fixed role in the decision, nor is there a fixed number of actions necessary for transfer. The Panel has recognized that the goals of the statute may readily be served by transfer of actions where a multitude of actions pend. Where, however, only a few related actions have been filed, a much stronger showing of benefits must be established. In one case the Panel refused transfer of one of two pending cases to the district where the other was filed, noting:

The two cases are not, in our opinion, exceptional cases sharing unusually complex questions of fact. If this litigation involved the number of cases generally associated with multidistrict civil treble damage antitrust litigation, the common questions of fact might be sufficient to invoke § 1407, but where, as here, there are a minimal number of cases involved in the litigation the moving party bears a strong burden to show that the common questions of fact are so complex and the accompanying common discovery so time-consuming as to overcome the inconvenience to the party whose action is being transferred and its witnesses.[1]

As put well by two astute commentators: “The MDL process is not simply a numbers game.”[2] For example, the Panel doesn't just count actions—where three actions pend in a district, but are consolidated, the Panel may count them as one action.[3] The Panel may also look more closely at the alternatives to transfer, looking to see if the benefits of transfer might be obtained by more modest means. In one case, the Panel declined to order one case to join a second case, for the reason that the cases were pending in adjacent federal courts in the same state.[4] The Panel has, on other occasions, transferred a single case to coordinate it with a single case.[5] The Panel applies a flexible standard to the factor of number of actions. In some instances the fact that there are few cases does not significantly diminish the potential value that transfer might have in reducing the overall burden of the litigation on the parties.[6] If the cases are relatively advanced, however, the Panel will be less likely to order transfer since the benefits to be derived from coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings will presumably be less.[7]

In considering the number of cases the Panel regularly considers potential tag-along cases.[8] The fact that additional actions are likely to be filed may affect the Panel's initial decision in the case and probably makes transfer more likely. The Panel has, however, also expressed its reluctance to consider the prospect of additional actions being filed, especially where the additional actions are being handled by the same lawyers as handling the existing cases.[9] If there is little prospect that additional actions will be filed, the fact that there are few pending actions will have greater weight.[10]

Where there are few actions pending, the Panel will be particularly sensitive to the prospects for managing the litigation voluntarily and without formal transfer by it.[11] Conversely, when ordering centralization of a small number of actions, the Panel appears particularly inclined to articulate specifically the benefits it sees flowing from transfer. In one case it transferred a single case to join another, but noted that transfer would eliminate duplicative discovery and prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.[12] The Panel may also “count” some actions differently from what the docket may show. If a group of actions has already been consolidated in some way in the districts where they were filed, the court may count the group of actions as one.[13]

Another indication of the important role the number of actions plays in the judgement of the Panel, where the number of pending actions increases dramatically, the Panel has ordered transfer nothwithstanding an earlier denial.[14] The mere prospect of additional actions, however, may not be persuasive to the Panel.[15]

In some ways, the number of actions functions as a proxy for the expected managerial complexity of the litigation. Where there are multiple actions with common counsel and common defendants, the Panel may treat them as a single action.[16]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

In re Scotch Whiskey, 299 F. Supp. 543, 544 (J.P.M.L. 1969) (footnote omitted) (emphasis in original); see also In re Air Crash near Canandaigua, N.Y., on September 16, 2002, 427 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2006). In re Advantage Investors Mortg. Corp. Mortg. Funds Litigation, 268 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Patent Litigation, 395 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (3 actions in 2 districts); In re Indian Tribes Contract Support Costs Litigation, 383 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (3 actions in 2 districts); In re Air Crash Near Yarmouth, Massachusetts on August 26, 2003, 381 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (3 actions in two districts); In re Sumatriptan Succinate Patent Litigation, 381 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (3 actions in 2 districts, 2 of which have already been consolidated); In re National Park Service Winter Use Management Litigation, 374 F. Supp. 2d 1347 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (2 actions in 2 districts); In re FedEx Ground Package System, Inc., Employment Practices Litigation, 366 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re Lawrence Moore/International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Litigation, 198 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2002); In re Plasma Display Panels Patent Litigation, 196 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2002); In re Molinaro/Catanzaro, 464 F. Supp. 966, 969 (J.P.M.L. 1979); In re 21st Century Productions Inc. “Thrilsphere” Contract Litigation, 448 F. Supp. 271, 272 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re Raymond Lee Organization, Inc. Securities Litigation, 446 F. Supp. 1266 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re Texas Instruments Inc. Employment Practices Litigation, 441 F. Supp. 928 (J.P.M.L. 1977); In re Commercial Lighting Products, Inc. Contract Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 392 (J.P.M.L. 1976); In re McDonnell Douglas “Wild Weasel AN/APR-38” Contract Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 387 (J.P.M.L. 1976); In re Interstate Medicaid Patients at Good Samaritan Nursing Center, 415 F. Supp. 389 (J.P.M.L. 1976); In re Pan American World Airways, Inc. Maternity Leave Policies Litigation, 414 F. Supp. 1232, 1234 (J.P.M.L. 1976); In re Royal American Industries, Inc. Securities Litigation, 407 F. Supp. 242, 243 (J.P.M.L. 1976); In re Brandywine Associates Antitrust and Mortg. Foreclosure Litigation, 407 F. Supp. 236 (J.P.M.L. 1976); In re Drowning Incident at Quality Inn Northeast, Washington, D. C., on May 3, 1974, 405 F. Supp. 1304, 1306 (J.P.M.L. 1976) (“Only two relatively simple negligence actions are involved here—too few and not complex enough to warrant transfer”); In re Air Crash Disaster Near Natchitoches Parish, Louisiana, on September 20, 1973, 391 F. Supp. 765, 766 (J.P.M.L. 1975) (“Since this leaves only two actions sharing common questions of fact, we find it difficult to justify transfer”); In re Shipley Co., Inc. Patent Litigation, 383 F. Supp. 847 (J.P.M.L. 1974); In re Nissan Motor Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 352 F. Supp. 960 (J.P.M.L. 1973). Accord In re Eli Lilly & Co. (Cephalexin Monohydrate) Patent Litigation, 446 F. Supp. 242, 243–44 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re Wyeth Patent Infringement Litigation, 445 F. Supp. 992, 993 (J.P.M.L. 1978) (transfer denied where only three actions pending); In re Luminex Intern., Inc. Products Liability Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 668, 669 (J.P.M.L. 1977) (same).
Mark Herrmann & David B. Alden, Drug and Device Product Liability Litigation Strategy 179 (2011).

See, e.g., In re Credit Suisse VelocityShares Daily Inverse VIX Short Term Exchange Traded Notes Securities Litigation, 326 F. Supp. 3d 1379 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018); In re: Quest Integrity USA, LLC, ('874) Patent Litigation, 148 F. Supp. 3d 1356 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015); In re: Hangtime, Inc., Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA) Litigation, 52 F. Supp. 3d 1375 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014).
See In re Bratton Litigation, 206 F. Supp. 2d 1366 (J.P.M.L. 2002). See also In re Mark Daniel Lyttle Litigation, 777 F. Supp. 2d 1342 (J.P.M.L. 2011).

See, e.g., In re Nebivolol ('040) Patent Litigation, 867 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (J.P.M.L. 2012); In re Simply Orange Orange Juice Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 867 F. Supp. 2d 1344 (J.P.M.L. 2012); In re Discover Card Payment Protection Plan Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 764 F. Supp. 2d 1341 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Prudential Insurance Company of America SGLI/VGLI Contract Litigation, 763 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Fresh and Process Potatoes Antitrust Litigation, 744 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2010); In re Capital One Bank Credit Card Interest Rate Hike Litigation, 716 F. Supp. 2d 1372 (J.P.M.L. 2010); In re Wholesale Grocery Products Antitrust Litigation, 663 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Fontainebleau Las Vegas Contract Litigation, 657 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Fairfield Greenwich Group Securities Litigation, 655 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re RBS Worldpay, Inc., Customer Data Security Breach Litigation, 626 F. Supp. 2d 1322 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Landamerica 1031 Exchange Services, Inc. Internal Revenue Service § 1031 Tax Deferred Exchange Litigation, 626 F. Supp. 2d 1345 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Standard Automotive Corp. Retiree Benefits “ERISA” Litigation, 431 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2006); In re Canon U.S.A., Inc., Digital Cameras Products Liability Litigation, 416 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2006); In re American Family Mut. Ins. Co., 416 F. Supp. 2d 1346 (J.P.M.L. 2006); In re Rhodia S.A., Securities Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (1 action transferred, but Panel notes 2 additional potential tag-along actions); In re Circular Thermostat Antitrust Litigation, 370 F. Supp. 2d 1355 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re Mosaid Technologies Inc., Patent Litigation, 283 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re Cisco Systems, Inc., Securities & Derivative Litigation, 268 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re Capital One Bank Credit Card Terms Litigation, 201 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2002); In re Philadelphia Life Ins. Co. Sales Practices Litigation, 149 F. Supp. 2d 937 (J.P.M.L. 2001); In re Literary Works in Electronic Databases Copyright Litigation, 2001 Copr. L. Dec. P 28198, 2000 WL 33225502 (J.P.M.L. 2000); In re White Consol. Industries, Inc., Environmental Ins. Coverage Lititgation, 1994 WL 52568 (J.P.M.L. 1994); In re Diamond Match Plant Hazardous Waste Cleanup Litigation, 799 F. Supp. 1204 (J.P.M.L. 1992); In re Pantopaque Products Liability Litigation, 787 F. Supp. 229 (J.P.M.L. 1992); In re Fairchild Industries, Inc., 1989 WL 162387 (J.P.M.L. 1989) (unpublished); In re Amoxicillin Patent and Antitrust Litigation, 449 F. Supp. 601, 603–04 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re General Aircraft Corp. Antitrust/Tort Claims Act Litigation, 449 F. Supp. 604 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re Petroleum Products Antitrust Litigation, 393 F. Supp. 1091, 1092–93 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re L. E. Lay & Co. Antitrust Litigation, 391 F. Supp. 1054, 1055 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re Eastern Airlines, Inc. Flight Attendant Weight Program Litigation, 391 F. Supp. 763 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re Japanese Electronic Products Antitrust Litigation, 388 F. Supp. 565, 567 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re West Coast Bakery Flour Antitrust Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 808 (J.P.M.L. 1974); In re Clark Oil & Refining Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 364 F. Supp. 458 (J.P.M.L. 1973); In re Camco Patent Infringement Litigation, 343 F. Supp. 1406 (J.P.M.L. 1972); In re Cross-Florida Barge Canal Litigation, 329 F. Supp. 543 (J.P.M.L. 1971); In re CBS Licensing Antitrust Litigation, 328 F. Supp. 511 (J.P.M.L. 1971); see also In re Omnitrition Intern., Inc. Securities Litigation, 1993 WL 52634 (J.P.M.L. 1993) (two actions transferred to join a third pending in transferee district); In re Amerada Hess Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 395 F. Supp. 1404, 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1975) (two actions transferred to district with one action pending); In re Air Crash Disaster Near Natchitoches Parish, Louisiana, on September 20, 1973, 391 F. Supp. 765, 766 (J.P.M.L. 1975) (transfer of three actions denied where only two shared common fact issues); In re Alodex Corp. Securities Litigation, 380 F. Supp. 790 (J.P.M.L. 1974) (single action transferred to coordinate with two actions pending in transferee district); In re Convenient Food Mart Franchise Litigation, 350 F. Supp. 1166, 1168 (J.P.M.L. 1972) (one action transferred to district where two actions pending); In re Value Line Special Situations Fund Litigation, 334 F. Supp. 999 (J.P.M.L. 1971) (same).

See, e.g., In re IBM, 302 F. Supp. 796, 799 (J.P.M.L. 1969). The Panel quoted the legislative history of 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407 quoted in this book in § 2:3. See also In re Willingham Patent, 322 F. Supp. 1019 (J.P.M.L. 1971) (one case ordered transferred to coordinate with two cases pending in transferee district).
See, e.g., In re Molinaro/Catanzaro, 464 F. Supp. 966, 969 (J.P.M.L. 1979). Advancement of cases towards trial is also an independent factor the Panel looks at to decide transfer. See § 5:35, below.

See, e.g., In re: Camp Lejeune, North Carolina Water Contamination Litigation, 763 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Celexa and Lexapro Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 652 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2009) (two actions in two districts, but Panel notes four additional potential tag-along actions in ordering transfer); In re Rhodia S.A., Securities Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (1 action transferred, but Panel notes 2 additional potential tag-along actions); In re Industrial Wine Contracts Securities Litigation, 386 F. Supp. 909, 912 (J.P.M.L. 1975).

See In re: California Wine Inorganic Arsenic Levels Products Liability Litigation, 109 F. Supp. 3d 1362 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015) (mere argument that additional actions will be filed not sufficient); In re Qualitest Birth Control Products Liability Litigation, 38 F. Supp. 3d 1388 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014), citing In re: Lipitor Antitrust Litigation, 856 F. Supp. 2d 1355 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2012); In re Zimmer, Inc., Centralign Hip Prosthesis Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 366 F. Supp. 2d 1384, 1385 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
See In re: Northeast Contaminated Beef Products Liability Litigation, 856 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2012); In re Fotomat Franchisee Litigation, 394 F. Supp. 798, 799 (J.P.M.L. 1975).

See, e.g., In re Sicilia Di R. Biebow & Co. Contract Litigation, 490 F. Supp. 513, 516 (J.P.M.L. 1980); In re Cable Tie Patent Litigation, 487 F. Supp. 1351, 1354 (J.P.M.L. 1980); In re Chiropractic Antitrust Litigation, 483 F. Supp. 811, 813 (J.P.M.L. 1980).

See, e.g., In re Starmed Health Personnel, Inc., Fair Labor Standards Act Litigation, 317 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2004); see also In re: Life Time Fitness, Inc., Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA) Litigation, 53 F. Supp. 3d 1378 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014).

See, e.g., In re: Hangtime, Inc., Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA) Litigation, 52 F. Supp. 3d 1375 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014) (4 actions essentially 2); In re Constellation Technologies LLC Patent Litigation, 38 F. Supp. 3d 1392 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014) (5 actions in two districts, but cases consolidated in one district and “related” in the other district, effectively making them 2 actions); In re American Family Mut. Ins. Co., 416 F. Supp. 2d 1346 (J.P.M.L. 2006) (2 actions, but at least one include collective action over 100 named plaintiffs); In re Bally Total Fitness Holding Corp. Securities Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (11 actions pending in two districts are functionally the equivalent to two actions in two districts because 10 in Oregon consolidated).

Compare In re FedEx Ground Package System, Inc., Employment Practices Litigation, 366 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (transfer denied) with In re Fedex Ground Package System, Inc., Employment Practices Litigation (No. II), 381 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (transfer ordered where number of actions had quadrupled).

See, e.g., In re SFPP, L.P., Railroad Property Rights Litigation, 121 F. Supp. 3d 1360 (J.P.M.L. 2015); In re Zimmer, Inc., Centralign Hip Prosthesis Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 366 F. Supp. 2d 1384, 1385 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (Panel declines to order transfer where previously denied). The Panel had denied transfer in In re Zimmer, Inc., 237 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
See In re Seaworld Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation (No. II), 118 F. Supp. 3d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2015).
